trial_identification.studytitle: Trypanosoma cruzi lineages and Chagas disease manifestations in cardiac unit patients from three endemic areas of Ecuador
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Evaluation of the prevalence of the cardiac form of Chagas disease and performance of rapid diagnostic tests in hospitals of endemic areas of Ecuador

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of infection and infectious agents

interventions.interventions: Evaluation of types and prevalence of electrocardiographic abnormalities in cardiac patients suffering from Chagas disease at the time of recrutiment into the study. Although the participation of each participant is limited to the time in which he/she is recruited into the study, participant recruitment is expected to span a total of 36 months.
interventions.comparator: Types and prevalence of electrocardiographic abnormalities in cardiac patients not suffering from Chagas disease

primaryOutcome.timepoint: At the time of patient recruitment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Electrocardiographic abnormalities (right bundle branch block, left bundle branch block, ventricular extrasystoles, altered ventricular repolarization, Q-waves, Atrioventricular block, sinoatrial node disfunction, supraventricular tachiarrithmia, atrial fibrilation)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the time of patient recruitment

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: All patients obtaining medical care at public hospitals in areas endemic for Chagas disease in Ecuador will be invited to participate in the study. All races will be included.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Any patients age one or younger will be excluded due to the difficulty of drawing blood from them and the discomfort they would suffer. If consent from the legal representative of a minor cannot be obtained at the time of the visit to the cardiologist, the minor will be excluded from the study.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study intends to determine the prevalence of cardiac damages associated with Chagas disease among patients of hospitals of endemic areas of Ecuador and to evaluate the performance of rapid diagnostic tests to be performed in such settings. We hypothesis that many of the patients attenging the hospital cardiac wards in endemic areas suffer from Chagas disease and that the use of rapid diagnostic tests might help the hospitals to attain better diagnosis.
